Title: 2023 New Year party
Text: In usual Sanctuary style, our New Year party brought together our community of refugees and volunteers, for food, fun and an array of talents. We enjoyed lots of musical skills from around the world, including a Ukrainian choir, Iranian and Japanese pianists, an oud-playing singer-songwriter and a Bangladeshi singer, among many other acts. Delicious food from Syria, Afghanistan, Ukraine and the UK was provided by guests. The Ukrainian choir, Volya Choir will be singing at Chichester Cathedral on Sunday 12th February at 11.15am, for a Sung Eucharist for Racial Injustice Sunday . They will also be performing at Give Peace A Chance! – a Ukraine benefit concert on Friday 24th February, 7:00pm at Assembly Rooms , Chichester. You can buy your tickets here . The event will feature renditions of The Beatles’ songs.

Title: Give Peace a Chance! – Benefit concert, featuring Ukrainian Volya choir
Text: The Give Peace a Chance! concert held in The Assembly Room on 24th Februrary (to mark a year on from the Russian invasion of Ukraine) was “defiant and joyous!”, reports our Trustee and Drop-in Lead, Jude Clouston. The concert was held to raise funds for Ukrainian refugees living locally. The room was packed and the Mayor of Chichester, Julian Joy, was among the audience members. The concernt included The Beatles’ music performed by cover act With The Beatles, and featured the Volya Ukrainian Choir, which was formed last year by Ukrainian women living locally, some of whom come to our weekly drop-in. The Volya Choir sang a number of traditional Ukrainian songs including last year’s Eurovision Song Contest winner, Stefania (KALUSH), as well as The Beatles’ song All You Need is Love and Give Peace a Chance by John Lennon and Yoko Ono. The choir – made up of women and children aged 3 to 60 who have all arrived in our area having escaped the conflict – performed at our New Year party too .

Title: New English support sessions for driving tests
Text: Not being able to drive is a significant barrier to gaining employment (and general independence) in our local area, because the public transport network doesn’t often provide the routes people need. We have therefore long been asked by refugees for support in getting their driving licence, whether it’s with English for driving terminology, volunteers providing driving practice, or help with filling out applications and making bookings. Kerry Foster, Pathways to Independence Manager , found that there is currently a large cohort among those we support who are at various stages of trying to get their driving licence, and that a major issue everyone is struggling with is lack of specialised English for taking the theory and practical tests. In response, Kerry has set up a weekly class which started last week and was very well attended. She is using DVLA resourced materials and will also be including information around vehicle maintenance, insurance, MOTs, tax and other aspects of driving in the UK that attendees have told us they struggle to understand. As part of registering for the class, participants fill a questionnaire about their previous driving experience, English language ability and background so we can gain a better understanding of people’s needs for future classes, and so that we can track their progress as part of their overall pathways to independence. As well as being able to pursue employment opportunities, driving enables people to attend medical appointments, go to the supermarket, take their family on outings etc – all journeys that refugees who don’t have a UK driving licence or car are reliant on our volunteers for. Classes are mixed gender (because, encouragingly, participants told us this would be acceptable) and aim to support cultural integration as part of wider learning on the terminology, rules and etiquette of UK roads. Attendees are from various countries and a diversity of backgrounds and cultures within each country, so these sessions will be really positive for cross-cultural solidarity as well as getting people ‘on the road’ to employment! Kerry said, “ It’s so fantastic that so many people have signed up for the class, and seeing that we are really meeting an unmet need. I’m looking forward to following people’s progress with getting their driving licence but also seeing how this impacts their overall route to independence and integration, and generally building a fulfilling life for themselves. “

Title: Sculptures and art cathedral exhibition celebrating resilience and values for Refugee Week
Text: Resilience in Clay is a an exhibition of seven heads of people who have made Chichester their home, by Sanctuary in Chichester (SiC) volunteer and sculptor Kate Viner, showing for three months from the 13th June. As part of this project, Kate has also been working with the SiC weekly women’s group and other members of our community including volunteers, to produce individual creative contributions on the topic of values in various media, which together will form a piece called A Common Thread, which will also be displayed alongside the sculptures and installed by the women’s group. Kate describes Resilence in Clay as, “ celebrating cultural values and what our new more diverse community brings to Chichester. It’s also a celebration also for aaaalll of Sanctuary. ” Everyone who is a part of SiC is invited to join in – “ the more the merrier! “. The whole process has been highly participatory from the beginning, with Kate centering the benefits of the project for the contributors and paid subjects. The women’s group has been working on their creations along with Kate at their weekly meet-ups, where they also have English lessons and we provide a crèche to allow those with small children to focus on their work. There are some very moving examples of people – both sculpture subjects and members of the women’s group – who were so lacking in self-belief at the start, that they avoided eye contact. Now they are full of confidence, producing their own art works and having fun joining in with group activities and discussions. The process of making oneself vulnerable as a sculpture subject or by sharing one’s own values and culture, and the resulting increase in trust and confidence has meant that people wanted to share their stories with Kate and with each other, providing a therapeutic outlet for them and building friendships. This is despite the fact that many of the women hardly speak any English and often don’t have a common language to communicate in – they’re supporting each other to express themselves. Kate says that, “ working on the values piece all together as a group has meant that there has been lots of bonding. It’s very moving to see how excited everyone is, and seeing people who have been here the longest, mainly from Syria, helping the newer arrivals, mainly from Afghanistan, and people taking it in turns to teach the others. ” To start with there was only one Ukrainian going to the women’s group but more have started coming along and wanting to get involved, so the project is encouraging bonding across various cultures. An example of values we’ve learned about is that in Afghanistan the central values are hospitality and optimism – this won’t surpise anyone who has been to an Afghan home; there is always an array of nuts and dried fruit on pretty dishes, ready for any unexpected visitors, and while guests are served tea there is usually some frying or baking going on, with the resulting delicious treats coming out of the kitchen a few minutes later. Kate describes the “flow of optimisim” that she sees “across the board”; “ The strength and resilience of everyone, and the sense of humour is extraordinary. What I have learned through this experience is absolutely backed up but what we’re trying to do here [at the charity] . I see it everyday. It’s a huge privilege so see people’s resilience and strength – I feel really proud of Sanctuary, and have a sense of respect for our community. I feel very emotional about the volunteers too, I think they are exrtaordinary and I am learning about everyone’s appreciation for Sanctuary. “ We look forward to seeing you at the cathedral! Gemma Driver

Title: Subjects of sculpture exhibition describe their experience of the project…
Text: The exhibition Resilience in Clay , by Sanctuary volunteer Kate Viner, is showing at Chichester Cathedral until the end of August. It consists of seven sculptures of the heads of members of our community, and throughout the creative process Kate has centred the benefits of the project to the subjects of her work. Here the subjects describe their experience of sitting for Kate and being a part of the project: “I am very happy with the whole project, and have a warm relationship with Kate. No present concerns but will ask you if I do. Kate has been superb at planning and coordinating the contributions from participants who could have been initially shy of contributing. She won their confidence, encouraged their embroidery and expressions of values, leading to several fine pieces I have seen. She asked me to contribute life thoughts and a small embroidery of the South Downs as well as a head. It has been a unique experience and an exciting prospect.” “I really enjoyed the whole process with Kate, she is amazing and so understanding. I can’t wait to see the exhibition “ “I’m very happy that I’m a part of this project. Kate is an amazing artist who can create realistic artwork that I admire. I had fun modeling for her.” “I enjoyed working with Kate, she is very attentive and sensitive. Posing for a sculpture is a completely new experience for me, but thanks to Kate, I felt absolutely no discomfort. I want to add to what has already been said that I enjoyed watching the work of a talented master – Kate. I’m glad to be a part of such a great project. When Kate asked me to be her model, I couldn’t believe that she was so interested in my face that she wanted to sculpt it. I never considered my face to be somehow beautiful or special. But Kate endeared me to her so much that I wanted to help her in this project. I also want to tell you and everyone involved in this project, thank you very much for raising such an important topic – refugees. Thanks “ “I would like to say that this was an amazing opportunity in many different ways.” “I personally found it so relaxing as I am currently taking an access course which is academic study plus balancing with my six children and working full-time. For me having one hour sitting down with a cup of coffee chatting with someone who has humanity and love like her (Kate) I found so relaxing.” “My current artwork will have the words ‘Where there is love, there is no darkness’. This means that love has the ability to push out darkness. I chose this phrase because love brings light, positivety, and understanding into our lives, creating an environment free from darkness or negativity. Love has the ability to transform and uplift individuals and communities, creating a more harmonious and compassionate world.” “It is a beautiful thing [taking part], and the most beautiful thing is that you hear a lot from people who support you.” “People who will come to this exhibition, I think, when they see these sculptures, they will think about the fate of the people depicted, what they had to endure, how they cope with all the difficulties in a foreign country. And maybe they will think about their lives, think how lucky they are that they live in a peaceful country and they do not need to run away from here trying to hide from some kind of danger. And they will appreciate every day they live even more, and hug their loved ones even tighter when they are nearby. I think this is the most important thing in life – to appreciate what you have, to appreciate the one who is next to you, to spend as much time with each other as possible and to tell your loved ones how dear they are to you. After all, we only have one life and it is so fleeting.” These quotes were given from before the exhibition opened, and the sitters have since been attending opening events, been interviewed by the BBC and more, so will undoubtedly have more to say on their more recent experiences of the project – we will post updates soon…

Title: A Culinary Journey: Exploring Syria Through Cuisine
Text: The inspiring story behind the new food business E&J Syrian Cuisine is one of resilience, perseverance, passion, a dream – and a love of food and cooking. Eyad and Joyhana arrived in Chichester four and a half years ago with their five children. Eyad, with years of experience in the culinary world, had established a street food restaurant in his hometown of Homs, Syria, before the war. “I have been cooking for a long time,” he shares. “I worked extensively in Syria and love working. My aim has always been to make customers happy with my food.” The couple set up their new food delivery service earlier this summer, delivering dishes to trial the business (our volunteers were their first customers, providing feedback and ideas for improvement), then starting their page on Deliveroo. They explain that the dishes all have their own culturally important histories and that they want trying the food to feel like a journey into the heart of Syrian culture. The menu celebrates the country’s rich culinary heritage, with each dish crafted with love and narrating a different story, from the bustling streets of Aleppo to the serene landscapes of the countryside. We recommend the aromatic Shawarma or the tasty Kabsa Rice, and for vegetarians, the Falafel Wrap is also a must-try. When asked about his dreams since arriving in the UK, Eyad’s aspirations are clear: “I dream of owning a restaurant where everyone comes to eat and leaves happy. If my financial situation improves, I want to help the less fortunate, especially orphaned children.” Setting up their own business in the UK has been transformative for the family after several years of struggle trying to get on their feet. Eyad describes the feeling as “stepping into the light from the dark, like stepping onto the moon.” His hopes for the future are simple yet profound: to meet his children’s and parent’s needs, travel with them, and own their own restaurant. Eyad said, “I want to thank Kerry, who dedicated much time to help us set up. Fern, who convinced and encouraged me to start this project. Simon for finalising the menu, and Toby and Pzemek for their contributions. Thank you to everyone who contributed to the initial food purchase; finally, thank you, Sanctuary in Chichester, for their unwavering support.” Kerry Foster, Sanctuary’s Pathways to Independence Manager, said, “It has been a pleasure supporting this family to realise their dreams.  When I was first introduced to the family, they had been here nearly four years and felt that they were not moving forward. They were desperate to utilise their skills and love of Syrian food and share this with their local community as well as become independent through working and running their own business.” E&J Syrian Cuisine has already garnered lots of positive reviews from the community. There was excellent volunteer feedback during the pilot, and positive reviews are also starting to come in on Deliveroo. ‘Very tasty and plenty. We all enjoyed it very much and will order again!’ and compliments on the friendly service, value for money and ‘Best hummus in a long while!’. Kerry continues: “There have been and continue to be many steps on their ‘pathway to independence’ and starting up a new business in a new country with many barriers to progress is no easy feat, but they are hardworking, motivated, proactive, resilient and determined and that is the recipe for success!” She added: “A big thank you to all the SiC volunteers who have and continue to support the family along their journey to independence” So why not give them a try? By supporting E&J Syrian Cuisine, you’re not just enjoying a meal but celebrating a culture, nurturing a personal dream, and becoming part of a larger human story.

Title: ‘Resilience in Clay’ Sculpture Subjects Describe Their Experiences at Cathedral Event
Text: As the Resilience in Clay exhibition at Chichester Cathedral comes to a close, a special In Conversation event was held at The Vicar’s Hall on the 26th August. The evening was hosted by the cathedral and Chichester Cathedral Friends. It began with an introduction from Interim Dean of Chichester, The Reverend Canon Simon Holland, followed by a moving talk from exhibition artist and Sanctuary volunteer Kate Viner. Sanctuary in Chichester trustee Philippa Gogarty provided an introduction to the challenges faced by asylum seekers, and the event concluded with a panel discussion featuring exhibition participants sharing their experiences. First of all, Simon gave his emotional and intellectual response to the exhibition, saying how it was at first uncomfortable for him to be confronted by the powerful sculptures every day at work. They made him challenge his own perceptions and views. Then, as time went by, and Simon processed his feelings, they became familiar and more comfortable, but no less moving. He thanked the sitters present for this enriching experience. Kate described how much she had learned from getting to know the seven sitters for her sculptures, each spending six three-hour sessions with the sculptor. She also paid tribute to the inspirational resilience shown by the sitters and read out some of the messages of welcome, encouragement and solidarity that had been left by visitors at the cathedral. Finally, Kate thanked Chichester Cathedral for their bravery in hosting the exhibition during their busiest months. Philippa gave the audience some of the insights she had gained from volunteering in Calais and then taking in a young asylum seeker called Asme who she and her husband Rory helped through the asylum application process while he was living with them. When she first met Asme, Philippa described her shock at the fact that there was nowhere on the planet that he could legally call home. The panel discussion was led by Simon and Gemma Driver, another Sanctuary in Chichester trustee, who asked the refugee panel about their experiences of the UK and of sitting for Kate, as well as how their participation in the exhibition has impacted them. All of them described what an eye-opening opportunity the exhibition had been and how Kate had been so kind and lacking in any judgment during the process. The panel consisted of: Donya from Iran, sculpture sitter and designer of the magazine that accompanied the ‘A Common Thread’ section of the exhibition (embroidered contributions on values from community members); Lyse from Burundi, sculpture sitter, student, care worker and mother to six children; Dalal from Syria who is currently volunteering with UK Harvest (and her son Walid who helped with translation); and Walid from Afghanistan, ex-BBC Afghanistan journalist, author of an article in the magazine on the increasing gender apartheid faced by women and girls in Afghanistan. Dalal described Kate as “so warm-hearted” and said that she had “learned a lot” from Kate. Lyse explained that she takes negative experiences and turns them into positives, and how this gives her strength. She never expected to go to university but is now about to start her degree at the University of Chichester. The experience of sitting for Kate, feeling listened to, building their friendship and having time away from her six children to reflect brought richness and additional strength to her life. Lyse also told the audience about being blown away by her friend crying when she came to see the sculptures – a common experience among many of the people present who had seen friends and strangers alike become emotional upon seeing the exhibition. Donya explained how being part of the exhibition and seeing it displayed in the cathedral has been “a spiritual experience” for her, while Walid spoke about how life has worsened for people in Afghanistan in the three months since he wrote the article, due to the Taliban’s increased oppression of women and girls, and how he appreciated the opportunity to write the article and express his point-of-view to exhibition visitors. At the end, another sitter who had been in the audience stood up to thank Kate. Pam is a volunteer with Sanctuary in Chichester and a guide at Chichester Cathedral as well as being descended from refugees, so it meant a lot to her to be part of the exhibition and to see visitors’ responses to it. She described her great respect for Kate’s work and how the three-hour sculpting sessions flew by because the conversation with Kate was so interesting. Finally, John Siebert, Chair of the Cathedral Friends thanked Kate for the exhibition and everything it had brought to the cathedral as well as to everyone who had seen it and everybody involved in it. We will post a recording of the event here shortly – hopefully next week…

Title: Giving Back: Beneficiaries’ Empowerment through Volunteering with UK Harvest and St Wilfrid’s Hospice
Text: Community is at the heart of what we do. We have started working with UK Harvest (food rescue and education charity) and St Wilfrid’s Hospice to help people give back and grow together. A major challenge for asylum seekers is that they are not allowed to work at all for the first year that their application is being considered, and are then only able to apply to work in certain roles that are on the UK’s ‘Shortage Occupation’ list – usually highly skilled jobs requiring qualifications they don’t have or within the care sector. Those who arrive with refugee status and are allowed to work still face a number of barriers to finding a job, and it takes time and perseverance to break through those barriers. In the meantime, volunteering can make a big difference. It gives people purpose, increased confidence and a routine, they learn about UK workplace culture and expectations (often very different from their countries of origin), they make friends from diverse backgrounds and learn new skills. Last month, we – along with UK Harvest and St. Wilfrid’s Hospice – helped four people to start volunteering. It’s part of how we support people to get ready for life in the UK and find the work they want to do. One of our recent additions to the team is Rahim (not his real name), who has joined the eCommerce team at St Wilfrid’s Hospice. He’s helping raise funds by listing donated items on eBay. His energy and enthusiasm have been a great boost to the team. We hope that Rahim will gain as much from his volunteering as the Hospice does from his hard work. Amina (not her real name), who recently came to Chichester, is now volunteering with UK Harvest and St Wilfrid’s. She said, “UK Harvest is doing something really good. I’m using my time positively, and I’m learning a lot. Volunteering at St. Wilfrid’s is a unique and positive experience for me.” Kerry Foster runs our Pathways to Independence (PTI) programme, supporting beneficiaries like Rahim and Amina on their own pathways by encouraging them to think about the steps they need to take towards future aspirations, and to set goals and milestones along the way. Kerry said, “Seeing a positive change in someone’s wellbeing through their volunteering work is priceless. Having spent time with individuals to understand and develop their own ‘pathways to independence’, for some, volunteering is a key step towards fulfilling their overall hopes and potential for their new life in the UK. Many of our beneficiaries were highly skilled and successful in their own countries, then find themselves having to start all over again in an environment that is new and daunting as well as having to support their children through school. Volunteering not only supports integration and allows individuals to give back to the community, it helps individuals begin to see what they have to offer the community and consider how their skills and knowledge could be adapted and transferred into the UK workforce.”  Collaborating with local charities to support people into volunteering is therefore an important development for the Pathways to Independence programme. Kerry sends, “A big thank you to Will Wallace, Volunteer Manager at UK Harvest, and Emma Lemm, Volunteer Services Manager at St Wilfrid’s, for providing these opportunities”. A representative of St Wilfrid’s said of the collaboration, “Supporting Sanctuary in their important cause has been a privilege for us in eCommerce”. These stories show how volunteering can change lives. It helps people gain transferable skills, self-esteem and become part of the community. If you are interested in volunteering with Sanctuary in Chichester, you could also benefit enormously from supporting individuals directly. For example, learning different perspectives and seeing people begin to thrive after facing so many difficulties and trauma – fill out our application form here .

Title: Celebrating Togetherness at Our Annual Summer Party &
Text: Summer Drop-Ins The much-anticipated summer party on July 31st was a huge success, despite the weather playing spoilsport. The marquee was abuzz with activity, and the array of cakes was a sight to behold. Chris North thoroughly entertained the children, and the Ukrainian Volya Choir’s music added to the festive spirit. One sentiment that stood out was the deep sense of belonging many felt. As one attendee put it, “This isn’t just a party; it’s a family reunion.” While it was a day of celebration, it was also a day of goodbyes as we bid farewell to Fern, who has been such an important part of the support we provide – thank you for all your hard work and dedication Fern, you will be missed! Beyond the summer party, our weekly drop-ins continued at full speed throughout July and August, with each gathering having its own fun features. At the beginning of July, despite the intermittent rain, the children had a blast playing outside and making slime indoors. As the weeks rolled on, art took centre stage. The craft table at the drop-in was bustling, and the diversity of donated materials led to some fabulous creations including some stunning painting-collage combinations. At the end of July, we welcomed Kateryna Tsarkova, a Ukrainian bandura player, who gave an impromptu recital. We also introduced two new members to our team, Claudie Fleming and James Field, who will be instrumental in supporting our beneficiaries. We also had visitors from the Community Programme at Pallant House Gallery, who introduced an exciting opportunity for our beneficiaries to be part of an upcoming exhibition – more info on this coming soon… The packed calendar continued into August, with cultural events and community activities as well as the drop-ins. Highlights included the Ukraine Independence Day celebration hosted by Volya Choir, and enriching discussions at the In Conversation event towards the end of the Resilience in Clay Exhibition at Chichester Cathedral . Additionally, Pallant House Gallery’s creative workshops were a hit, especially those with the theme of crafting 3-D cats, and the ESOL Summer School also saw enthusiastic participation . A heartfelt thank you goes to everyone who attended, volunteered and contributed to the summer party, drop-ins and other events.

Title: Report on Our Summer Intensive English Course
Text: The biggest barrier people face in building their new lives in the UK is a lack of English. Finding work, dealing with bureaucracy, schools, healthcare, understanding systems and making friends are all very difficult without English and our volunteers spend a lot of time helping with these things when people who don’t speak English first arrive. We also have a team of qualified volunteer English for Speakers of Other Languages (ESOL) tutors, who support individuals to make real progress in English. This August, our volunteer tutors ran a special intensive two-week summer ESOL course for 13 students. It covered practical topics like finding a job in the UK, understanding schools, staying safe on the roads, health and wellbeing. One fun part was a tour of Chichester, where – after a classroom session on history and geography – everyone learned more about the city’s history, led by one of our tutors who is a professional tour guide. The course ended with a party, where everyone practised English conversation and played some traditional English party games. The highlight of the party was singing a sea shanty led by another of our tutors who is a professional singer. Thanks to our trustee and ESOL Lead, Lois Smith, our awesome tutors and of course our determined learners, the course was a big success. One student said, “This wasn’t just about learning English; it was about finding a sense of belonging.” We’re also excited that our volunteers have supported 12 more people to sign up for ESOL lessons at Chichester College. Now, over 22 of our friends are learning English there. It’s a big step towards feeling at home in the UK and finding work. If you’re an ESOL teacher and would like to give some of your time to supporting refugees, come and join us !

Title: Meet New Members of Sanctuary’s Team: Claudie and James
Text: We are delighted to introduce you to the latest additions to the Sanctuary in Chichester family — Claudie Fleming and James Field. Both bring unique skills and perspectives to our team, and we are very pleased to have them on board. Claudie joins us after recently graduating and is eager to dive into her role as Volunteer Coordinator. Claudie tells us: “I’ve been warmly welcomed into the Sanctuary community, and I’m thrilled to be part of this hardworking team. I’ve already had the pleasure of meeting people from diverse backgrounds, and I look forward to learning more and developing skills that will aid me in a career working with refugees and asylum seekers.” James is no stranger to Sanctuary in Chichester, having been with us at the very beginning, now returning to continue his impactful work after a career as a Headteacher. A word from James: “I’ve spent most of my career in education, and it’s a joy to return to Sanctuary in Chichester. The organisation has grown tremendously, and I’m excited to work alongside committed individuals like Claudie, Kerry, Steve, and our Trustees.” James continues: “My focus is on helping refugees across the area in various ways, and it’s rewarding to be part of such a meaningful mission.” We’re excited to see the contributions Claudie and James will make to our community!

Title: Trustee Mike Runs the Great South Run For Sanctuary in Chichester
Text: Mike Mansergh, a cornerstone of our Board of Trustees, is gearing up for his fourth appearance in the Great South Run. Mike works so hard for the organisation on a voluntary basis but has somehow found time to train for the run, and this year he is of course raising money for Sanctuary in Chichester. Thank you Mike! In Mike’s words: “As the countdown to my fourth Great South Run dwindles to just one month, my enthusiasm is at an all-time high. This year, I’ve chosen to run for a cause that’s close to my heart—Sanctuary in Chichester. The tireless efforts of our volunteers are instrumental in helping individuals who have endured severe hardships find a new home in our community. It’s a privilege to contribute to such a meaningful mission.” Mike’s dedication to our mission is clear: “Sanctuary in Chichester stands as a pillar of hope for those who have been stripped of their homes and faced life-altering trauma. My volunteer work has allowed me to witness the transformative power of our initiatives, which pave the way to independence for those we serve. None of this would be possible without essential financial backing.” How you can support Mike: If you’re inspired by Mike’s amazing commitment and would like to contribute to our work, please donate to his Great South Run fundraising page.

Title: Volunteer Training Day
Text: Last Monday, 18th September, we held a volunteer training session at St Paul’s Church Community Centre in Chichester. The focus of the event was to provide our volunteers with the necessary skills and information to support refugees and asylum seekers on an ongoing basis effectively. It was a focused and productive event with around 30 people attending. This training is essential for aligning volunteers with the mission of Sanctuary in Chichester, and topics covered included family review meetings, goal setting, and Job Centre interactions, among others. These training events are held regularly throughout the year to ensure that volunteers have the necessary information and skills to perform their roles effectively, whether they are Befrienders, English Tutors or contribute in other ways like running our social events. Some of our volunteers have multiple roles. The training was led by Philippa Gogarty, Trustee and Befriending Lead at Sanctuary in Chichester. Philippa provided insights based on her extensive experience, offering practical advice and guidelines for volunteers. During the training session, key members of the Sanctuary team shared valuable insights that spanned various aspects of our work. Philippa outlined her role and emphasised the importance of family review meetings for new arrivals. Claudie Fleming, our new Volunteer Coordinator, introduced herself and discussed the significance of setting goals for beneficiaries. Kerry Foster, Pathways to Independence Manager, provided an overview of how to interact with the Job Centre and stressed the necessity of supporting refugees to keep their Universal Credit journals updated. Trustee Mike Mansergh, who is deeply involved in the organisation, echoed the importance of maintaining updated Universal Credit journals. Trustee Evie Owen announced her new role as Schools Liaison Lead, in which she aims to keep everyone updated on school-related matters for the children we support – a highly complex challenge. One of the standout moments of the day was the discussion about the possibility of offering IT training sessions to beneficiaries. This initiative is geared towards improving their digital literacy, an increasingly important skill in today’s world, and one that many refugees and asylum seekers are missing. The event wrapped up with breakout sessions where volunteers were divided into groups based on their roles —tutors, Befrienders, and drop-in volunteers. These focused discussions allowed for a deeper understanding of each role’s unique challenges and opportunities. A critical update was shared regarding potential Home Office changes that could reduce the time for finding housing from 28 days to just seven days for those whose asylum applications are accepted. This presents a significant challenge for the refugees and our organisation, as it’s already very difficult to secure housing and employment within the current 28-day window. Given these potential changes, ongoing training and support for Befrienders will be more important than ever. The insights and skills shared during the training session will be invaluable tools for navigating these challenges. While the work of Befrienders has always been vital, these potential changes could make their role even more critical in ensuring the wellbeing and successful integration of our beneficiaries. Thank you to all the volunteers who attended the training session. Your commitment to the cause is what makes our work possible, and we appreciate your dedication to supporting refugees and asylum seekers in our community. Lastly, a special thanks to St Paul’s Church for generously providing us with the venue for the training session. Trustee Mike Mansergh is running the Great South Run in aid of Sanctuary in Chichester in October. Find out how to support him by donating here .

Title: Update: Sanctuary in Chichester Response to Asylum Hotel
Text: Sanctuary in Chichester is gearing up to support the people housed in the hotel. This weekend some of our trustees and staff met many of the men, women and children who are accommodated there to assess how best we can support them, and work is now underway to help meet their needs. Thank you for all the messages of support. Some people have asked how they can help and there are two things that would make a big difference: donating so we can buy items or services that we are unable to source for free, and becoming a volunteer with us . Our awesome team of volunteers carry out the majority of the organisation’s vital work, and we provide the training and support needed to make it as rewarding as possible. We don’t have storage or capacity to deal with donated items, so we are very grateful to be able to source them through our partner organisations according to individual needs. If you have items you would like to donate (good condition clothes, shoes, toys etc), please drop them off at My Sister’s House, 44 Bognor Road, Chichester PO19 7TG. BECOME A DONOR

Title: Sanctuary Selects: A Collaboration with Pallant House Gallery
Text: We are thrilled to announce ‘ Sanctuary Selects ‘, a special exhibition of works curated by local refugees and asylum seekers at Pallant House Gallery. The project showcases the power of art to transcend language and cultural barriers, offering a fresh perspective on community collaboration, and is the result of the continued partnership between Sanctuary in Chichester and the gallery, and the desire of Pallant House Gallery to be as inclusive as possible in their provision. Marcus and a Pink By Patrick Procktor About the Exhibition Over the past few months, participants from Sanctuary have had the opportunity to explore Pallant House Gallery’s remarkable collection of 20th and 21st-century prints and ceramics from the Golder-Thompson Gift. They selected pieces that resonated with them and shared their responses through accompanying labels. This has sparked meaningful conversations among participants about art’s diverse interpretations and emotional impacts. Bec Hopkins, a volunteer with Sanctuary in Chichester ( and local artist ) who has been coordinating this project said: “Art transcends languages and connects all of us. What better way to learn from each other than to enjoy art? This exhibition serves as a platform for refugees and asylum seekers to share their perspectives and experiences with the wider community, aligning with the shared goals of Pallant House Gallery and Sanctuary in Chichester.” Sanctuary Selects: Voices from our Community is a FREE exhibition and runs from 6 October 2023 until 4th February 2024 in the Print Room at Pallant House Gallery . The Female Quixote By Stephen Chambers

Title: Run Complete! Mike Mansergh Completes the Great South Run for Sanctuary
Text: Sanctuary in Chichester Trustee Mike Mansergh has successfully completed the Great South Run. Mike finished the race in an impressive 1 hour and 18 minutes, and his fundraising efforts (as well as endurance!) have really gone the extra mile. Fundraising Update Mike’s fundraising page has already collected £1263, and donations are still incoming. The page will remain open for a few more days for those who still wish to contribute, please do here . What’s Next? The funds raised will go a long way in supporting the work we do here at Sanctuary in Chichester. From providing essential basics to asylum seekers to paying for essentials to help refugees into work, every pound raised makes a real difference – especially as our staffing costs are paid for through grants, which we are extremely grateful for, and means that all other donations go directly to those we support. A Big Thank You from Mike Himself “I did the run largely due to the enormous generosity and kindness of so many in supporting my fundraising effort. Sanctuary in Chichester will be extremely appreciative of the many donations I have received. I would like to thank everyone for showing such interest in our small, but vitally important charity in Chichester, which is helping look after increasing numbers of traumatised people arriving in our area. Thank you all!”

Title: A Tribute for Joy Constantin
Text: We are very sad to announce the death of Joy Constantin, a much-loved volunteer who brought huge enthusiasm, creativity and joy to the children at the drop-in craft table. Here is a tribute for her from her friend and craft table colleague, Lynne Waylen. It has been a pleasure and a privilege to work alongside fellow volunteer Joy Constantin at the Sanctuary drop-in. It was obvious from our first joint art session that Joy delighted in the company of children, encouraging them to play and create or just talk. Never short of conversation, warm and welcoming, the children were naturally drawn to her genuine interest in them as individuals. She gave them time and space to develop their skills both creative and linguistic at their own pace. Joy certainly lived up to her name, always cheerful and positive, even when – as many of you would have witnessed – it was clear that she was struggling with fatigue in the latter stages of cancer. A tour de force, a successful creative business woman who throughout her life supported many less fortunate than ourselves. For her 80th birthday she asked friends not to bring her gifts, but to donate towards a fund enabling children at Sanctuary to enjoy a day out. Generous and caring, fun to be with, Joy will be greatly missed and remembered with much affection. Lynne.

Title: Latest Update: The Hotel
Text: When refugees first arrive in the Chichester area, our first priority is to help them feel welcome and safe. With that in mind it has been lovely to welcome lots of the new residents of the local hotel to our weekly women’s group and drop-ins, and we expect to see numbers rise as people become familiar with their surroundings and get to know us. We’re also doing what we can in providing transport to these important social events, and our volunteers are stepping up as usual to give lifts to those who can’t walk far – those with small children or who have disabilities or are unwell. We had a record-breaking 132 people at the last drop-in , and with this big increase in attendees, we need additional volunteers (apply here!) for various roles, including managing the Welcome Desk, assisting with children’s activities, helping with refreshments and transport. We’re collaborating with the hotel’s management, West Sussex County Council, and other local groups to support the new arrivals, and are providing clothes, shoes, pushchairs and prams (so families with children can leave the hotel) and toys among other items. We’ve given SIM cards and phones to those without and the recipients have been very grateful. We’re also getting to grips with where along the process everyone’s asylum applications have got to so we can advise them on what to expect next and support them in communicating with the Home Office. We hope to soon have news of hairdressers who got in touch with us to generously volunteer to cut hotel residents’ hair – we’re just waiting for their DBS checks to come through. We have been inundated with kind offers of donations and support – a big thank you to everyone who has donated or got in touch! We are especially grateful to the Rotary Club for their help in sourcing and providing the items needed. We’re also grateful to My Sister’s House, including for accommodating a large number of women at their recent free clothing pop-up. If you would like to help and you are able to give us your time, please apply to become a volunteer . If you have good condition clothing, shoes or toys to donate, please take them to the new My Sister’s House, 44 Bognor Road, Chichester PO19 7TG. If you would like to donate funds , every pound makes a real difference, especially as our staffing costs are paid for through grants, which we are extremely grateful for, so all other donations go directly to those we support. A big thank you to all our volunteers working with hotel residents and at the women’s group and drop-in! Photo by Julia M Cameron: https://www.pexels.com/photo/people-sorting-donations-6994963/

Title: Sanctuary in Chichester AGM 2023
Text: Sanctuary in Chichester recently held its Annual General Meeting at The Vicar’s Hall, marking a year of significant progress and setting the stage for future challenges and opportunities. Members received the annual report and an update on the charity’s finances. All current trustees were elected to continue for another year and members welcomed a new trustee Dr Waleed Hussein. Key highlights of the AGM other than the trustee election included substantial growth described in updates on the drop-in and the befriending programme, the launch of a schools liaison project, and an outline of how we are responding to the evolving needs of beneficiaries with the designation of a local hotel to house asylum seekers. Tony Toynton, said of the meeting: “It was lovely to get together with fellow trustees, volunteers, and staff to look back on a very busy year for our charity and then set out our plans to meet the significant challenges we’re already facing in this current year. It also allowed me to thank everyone for their amazing support to refugees and asylum seekers in the Chichester area.” Looking Forward As Sanctuary in Chichester moves into another year, the AGM served as a reminder of the charity’s vital role in the community. The dedication of its volunteers and staff, coupled with the support of the community, continues to make a profound difference in the lives of those seeking refuge and a new start in Chichester.

Title: Bertie the Cathedral Cat: A Heartwarming Tail
Text: Chichester Cathedral and Sanctuary in Chichester have joined forces again in efforts to support refugees and asylum seekers locally and to help ensure everybody feels welcome at the Cathedral. The digital story ‘Bertie the Cathedral Cat’ is a central feature of the collaboration, which will debut on December 3rd. This animated tale, narrated by The Reverend Canon Simon Holland and illustrated by Chloe Robertson, tells the story of Bertie, a cat who finds his way into the Cathedral and welcomes a family to join the Christmas festivities. The story will be available on the Cathedral’s website and social media channels. Interactive Christmas Trail at the Cathedral The Cathedral will be hosting a special Christmas Trail to celebrate the story’s release. Visitors can join the fun by searching for Bertie hidden amongst the Cathedral’s treasures and artworks. Successful participants will be rewarded with a festive decoration for their Christmas tree, adding an interactive and engaging element to the experience. In addition, the Orders of Service will be in multiple languages to help those whose English is not their native language. Volunteer Support and Community Involvement Throughout Advent and Christmas, the Cathedral will also be actively encouraging community members to support Sanctuary by volunteering with us or donating. This is very welcome, as with the recent doubling in beneficiaries we will need all the support we can get to maintain and expand our services, such as the weekly drop-ins, English tutoring, the weekly women’s group, Nations United football, help with the asylum process and various other support activities. Sanctuary in Chichester expresses deep gratitude for Chichester Cathedral’s ongoing support. This partnership helps us to addresses the immediate needs of our beneficiaries as well as plan our future work, and sets the stage for continued collaboration, enhancing our collective impact on the lives of refugees and asylum seekers.

Title: ‘Welcome to Britain’: The Colouring Book for Hope
Text: At Sanctuary in Chichester, we recently experienced a heartwarming gesture of solidarity and support for our young refugees and asylum seeker children, with a testament to the power of art and community. The Professional Cartoonists Organisation , moved by the removal of child-friendly murals at the Kent Intake Unit for unaccompanied asylum-seeking children in Dover, decided to take a stand. The murals, which were ordered to be removed by the Immigration Minister , had been a source of comfort and welcome for the children. Cartoonists Unite for a Cause In response to this disheartening event, renowned cartoonists, including the likes of Quentin Blake and Terry Gilliam, came together to create a ‘ Welcome to Britain ‘ colouring book. This initiative was not just about creating a book; it symbolised solidarity and a message to these young souls that they are welcomed and valued in the UK. The cartoonists generously offered their talents for free, and 38 Degrees supported the cause by running a fundraiser to cover printing and postage costs. Cartoon Delivery We received a generous delivery of thirty copies of the book and some crayons, which we distributed during one of our November Drop-in sessions. These gifts were particularly cherished by the children being housed at the hotel. Our heartfelt thanks go to everyone who contributed to this thoughtful gesture.

Title: 38 Degrees' Colouring Books
Text: In the summer of 2023, the Home Office ordered that cartoon murals in children's asylum centres be painted over as the colourful animations were considered to be too welcoming. In response, positive action group '38 Degrees' asked several top cartoonists to create drawings about life and culture in Britain, which resulted in a children's colouring book. Our wonderful volunteer, Maggie Berrill, managed to get hold of 30 copies of the book which was positively received by children at the Re-Act playgroup. The remaining copies will go into Welcome Packs for new arrivals.

Title: Statement on missing children in Brighton & Hove
Text: It was reported this week* that more than 70 children had disappeared from a Hove hotel used by the Home Office to house unaccompanied young asylum seekers.  It follows the revelation in the Guardian newspaper in October that more than 220 unaccompanied children were missing from hotels funded by the Home Office, which was rightly described as a catastrophic child protection failure. This statement is on behalf of organisations supporting people who have sought sanctuary in Brighton & Hove, ahead of a debate at a full council meeting of Brighton & Hove City Council on Thursday 15 December. We are shocked to learn of the appalling number of children going missing.  One child is too many and, if they were British, it would cause serious alarm and concern.  70 children going missing in this City of Sanctuary is a scandal. Brighton & Hove City Council has duties under the Children Act 1989 and 2004 to safeguard and promote the welfare of all children in need. It needs to do more to discharge that duty for unaccompanied asylum seeking children. An investigation is needed urgently into what has gone wrong , the complex reasons behind young people absconding and how they can be addressed. We are ready to support that. But the fundamental problem is that hotels are no place for lone children.  Only local authorities can be corporate parents. The Home Office must find a way to put children directly into Councils care as soon as they arrive in the country and not place them in limbo in hotels where they are vulnerable to the traffickers who prey on them. Asylum hotels are no place for any child. Some children in Brighton & Hove have been living in an hotel funded by the Home Office for more than a year. We hear from doctors and teachers, as well as their parents, that they are simply not thriving: their physical and mental health is suffering. It is vital that the Home Office speed up its asylum decisions, clear the backlog and stop warehousing people in hotels. * We are not linking to that report as it names the three hotels used by the Home Office in Brighton & Hove. This irresponsible journalism puts the residents at unnecessary risk from traffickers and others who might wish them harm. This statement is supported by a network of groups that support refugees and migrants in Brighton & Hove, including: Best Foot Music Brighton & Hove Stand Up To Racism Brighton Quakers Sanctuary Group Care4Calais Care for Our City Cornerstone Community Centre (Hove) Hummingbird Project Make Amplify Migrant English Project Network of International Women Refugee Radio Refugee Council Sanctuary on Sea Sussex Interpreting Services Thousand for 1,000 Voices in Exile

Title: Sign up for an info session to find out more about how to apply to university in the UK as a Refugee/Asylum seeker
Text: 31 October 2023 Applying to University in the UK – for refugees and people seeking asylum Are you a refugee or seeking asylum in the UK interested in applying to university? STAR is running this session to introduce you to the process. What will the session cover? An introduction to the university application process, covering both undergraduate and postgraduate applications. It will include: An overview of how to apply to university in the UK Key tips for your application Information about scholarships and additional support What if I need more support? We will be running two follow-up online events (the first shortly after the info session and the second in 2024) where you will have the opportunity to speak to a current student about your application. Spaces are limited and we’ll share details of how to register your interest during this information session. Here’s what previous attendees have said: ‘Everything was good and helpful. I got all the needed information. Thank you’ ‘It was great in all aspects guiding students to courses, university choice, student general life, student finance support etc. So keep it on and thanks.’ We will also be sharing information about other resources and organisations that can offer support for your university application. Sign me up! How do I attend? This information session will take place on Zoom. Register for your free place , and you will receive full details about how to access the event by email. If you have limited internet access, you can also dial into the Zoom meeting from a mobile phone. The event will be recorded and available on STAR’s YouTube channel afterwards.

Title: Open up safe routes to the UK for those seeking refuge from the Gaza/ Israel conflict
Text: 23 October 2023 We are horrified by the escalating violence and the unacceptable targeting of civilians in Gaza and Israel. Our thoughts are with everyone affected and those who have lost loved ones and who are worried about friends and family. As UN independent experts state “There is no justification for violence that indiscriminately targets innocent civilians, whether by Hamas or Israeli forces. This is absolutely prohibited under international law and amounts to a war crime.” STAR is all about creating a welcome in the UK for people who are forcibly displaced and need a place of safety to rebuild their lives. This includes ensuring that people are provided with the safe routes they need to get here. We called for safe routes for people caught up in violence when Russia invaded Ukraine, when the Taliban took over Afghanistan, and when civil war broke out in Sudan. Now we call for safe routes once again. No one should be forcibly displaced from their home, something which is against international law. However, people who feel they have no choice but to leave their country need access to safety. Gaza is a densely populated area, only 25 miles long, with a civilian population of 2.2 million people. Almost half of whom are children and 7 in 10 of whom are already refugees. Since 2007, Gaza has been subject to a strict land and sea blockade by Israel that prevents civilians and vital necessities such as food and medicine from easily moving across the border. Before the current crisis the World Food Programme estimated that more than 60% of Gaza’s population faced food insecurity. The recent escalation of the blockade of Gaza, which cut off supplies of power, water and food, and the continual bombing campaign by Israel is causing an extreme humanitarian crisis. There is nowhere safe for people to go in Gaza to escape the violence, and they can’t leave as the borders to neighbouring countries are closed. We call on the UK government to open up safe routes to the UK for those who need them and  implement an urgent family reunion scheme. We also continue our call for a fair and humane asylum system in the UK which upholds the right to asylum no matter how someone travels here, with safe routes in place that provide refugees, no matter where they come from, with a means of seeking safety in the UK. We also added our name to the call led by the Refugee Council asking emergency safe passage for people impacted by the violence in Israel and Palestine. For further background information on conflict, you can have a look at United Nation website.

Title: No Dad Jokes Without Dad
Text: Help us change the law to reunite refugee children with their parents. 21 September 2023 Did your dad tell the worst jokes? Maybe you’re the joker in your family? Now you can share your bad dad jokes for a good cause. We’re collecting the UK’s favourite dad jokes to raise awareness of refugee children torn apart from their parents by war. “I haven’t seen my family for nearly three years now… I cannot explain what this feels like… Being without your family, it is like you have a body without a soul.” Habib*, 17, Sudan (*name changed to protect identity) Along with more than 100 other charities, we’re calling for a change in the law that would allow refugee children in the UK to bring their parents to join them in safety. How you can help Collect your neighbourhood’s cheesiest dad jokes Ask as many people as possible to give you their favourite dad joke. We’ll compile all the jokes into a joke book to present to the government at the end of the campaign. Send your friends, family and neighbours the link to submit their cheesiest joke via the Refugee Council website or print out a form to collect the jokes in person. [ Link to PDF for printing ] Distribute campaign flyers Do you have a regular pub quiz? Maybe there’s a comedy club or a theatre near you? We want to distribute our flyers wherever dad jokes are likely to be found. Contact us to request flyers [communications@star-network.org.uk] Take part in our Dad Jokes TikTok challenge Stay tuned for the launch of our No Laugh Challenge. We’ll be updating this blog with the details. Organise a postcard-writing session We have prepared postcards for local campaign groups to send to their MPs. The postcards have space for your to write your own dad joke. Contact us [communications@star-network.org.uk] if you could organise a postcard writing session for your local campaign group. Thank you so much for your help to raise awareness of the unfair laws separating refugee families. Together, we can change the law to reunite families torn apart by war and oppression

Title: Why you should join STAR in 2023-2024
Text: 12 September 2023 If you’re heading to university this year, why not join the largest network of students building a society where refugees are welcomed! Get the most out of your uni experience by joining a society where you can make a real difference in your local community and across the UK. Last year, 2005 STAR students at 39 universities volunteered in their communities, campaigned for refugee rights, and learned about asylum and refugees with experts and peers! http://star-network.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/Why-you-should-join-STAR-3.mp4 Here’s what Coventry Refugee and Migrant Centre had to say about the STAR students making a difference in their organisation: “I can’t thank the STAR volunteers enough for the amazing work they have done with us this year. They have shown commitment, resilience, curiosity and involvement with and for our young people and the young people really enjoyed their presence. I am looking forward to collaborating again next academic year” – Coventry Refugee and Migrant Centre Check out the Student Action for Refugees (STAR) student society at your university – or if there isn’t one, you can set one up ! Don’t just take our word for it – hear more about why you should join STAR from our STAR leaders themselves! “I am so proud to be a member of STAR and am really excited to fight for more social injustices together with my fellow STAR members around the UK!” – Shehany, Plymouth STAR and Equal Access Activist “Volunteering with STAR for the conversation classes, the homework club and the bike scheme is incredibly eye-opening. It is a great way to help refugees and asylum seekers in our local community whilst educating myself on the obstacles they are up against. Therefore, it is both enriching and rewarding and I would recommend it to anyone that has the chance to get involved.” – STAR volunteer at Leeds English conversation club “Volunteering as part of a larger STAR network challenges the idea that your contribution is small. As STAR student leaders, we’re a small cog in a very big wheel making the UK a more welcoming place for refugees.” – Peter, Cardiff STAR “There are many ways to get involved, whether you prefer to interact personally, or to contribute behind the scenes. It’s a great way to better understand the depth of the refugee and asylum-seeking community, past media portrayals and over-simplistic blanket descriptions.” – Jiayi, KCL STAR

Title: Good news for refugees wanting to study in the UK
Text: 11 September 2023 Student finance rules are changing from 2025. In this blog, you can read about the eligibility of refugees who could not access student finance due to the Equivalent or Lower Qualification (ELQ) rule and how STAR and partner organisations have called for the removal of this unfair rule. The government has announced that the restrictive Equivalent or Lower Qualification (ELQ) rule will be removed in 2025 when the new Lifelong Loan Entitlement is introduced . What is the ELQ (Equivalent or Lower Qualification) rule? In September 2007, the government announced that it would no longer provide public funding for Home/EU students studying for a qualification that is equivalent to, or of a lower level than, one that the student already holds. This means that if you already have a first degree (e.g. BA, BSc) and wish to study for another undergraduate degree, you cannot currently access a student loan to fund your studies – even if your previous qualification was completed overseas. This rule puts refugees who wish to requalify or need to restart their studies in the UK in a marginalised and disadvantaged position. Case study: A student was trafficked to the UK and this experience influenced her decision to study law in the UK, in the hope that she might one day be able to support other survivors of trafficking. She gained a sanctuary scholarship to study at university in the UK but as soon as she received her refugee status, she was no longer eligible for the scholarship. She was also unable to access student finance as she had a previous degree in literature from her home country. Fortunately, she was able to access private charitable funding to pay her course fees to allow her to continue with her studies, but she has faced intense financial pressure and hardship as she struggles to combine full-time study with working to cover her accommodation and living expenses. What is changing? Last year, STAR, in collaboration with the Refugee Council and Refugee Education UK , wrote to the government about how the ELQ rule has unfairly banned refugees from continuing their studies in the UK by presenting case studies from refugee students who encountered huge barriers to pursuing their education because of this rule. Since refugees come here out of necessity rather than choice, we argued they should be eligible to access funding for their higher education. From 2025, under the Lifelong Loan Entitlement, refugee students will have access to government funding for equivalent qualifications that they already hold. Even though this change will not take place immediately, this is a big step forward, as the rule has had a damaging impact on refugees’ ability to integrate and build new lives here. Removing the ELQ rule will give more refugees the chance to access further and higher education. This will help them gain new skills and qualifications so they can support themselves and have Equal Access to higher education. Their presence at universities also contribute to bringing a more inclusive and diverse environment. There is still work to be done to ensure the new system is fair and accessible. We’ll be monitoring the situation closely with our partners. But this is very welcome news for refugees wanting to study in the UK. We are pleased the government listened to the concerns we jointly raised. Our advocacy was done in partnership with the Refugee Council and Refugee Education UK, which shows the power of collaboration for better change. We also want to show our gratitude to refugee students for sharing their stories with us. To find out more about access to student finance in the UK, check GOV.UK and the UKCISA website.

Title: STAR’s new stickers: A big thank you to FastPrint!
Text: 25 August 2023 The STAR team is busy gearing up for the start of the new year and STAR groups will soon be receiving a box full of great resources for freshers week. Inside that box are stickers, provided to us by the FastPrint team. The STAR team wants to thank FastPrint for providing us with high-quality stickers. We’ve now got a range of stickers to spread the message of making the UK a more welcoming place for refugees and people seeking asylum, including brand new stickers to support our Equal Access campaign.
